When we are in the majority next term, I’ll be there implementing our right to investigate, and issue and enforce subpoenas as a ranker on Oversight, because my vote just protected our right to do so. (6/6) 

https://t.co/CmpTuAWmq4

I’ve made some promises to the Lowcountry. And I promised to follow the Constitution. I also said I would not blindly follow partisan politics, but rather vote for what is right — not for what is politically expedient — and, most importantly, represent our district. (5/6)

This vote wasn’t about whether the Jan. 6th committee should exist or the merits of the subpoena itself. The question was simply: Does Congress have the ability to issue and enforce its subpoena power? I believe it does, and our courts do, too. (4/6)
During Benghazi we issued subpoenas for materials and testimony, and we didn’t let a single person just walk away from our process. (3/6)

When Republicans were in control, we used this power to investigate Benghazi and even compelled Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to testify (the Benghazi committee was created in the same exact way as the Jan. 6th committee). We’ve used this power many times. (2/6)

Congress has certain powers, and they are an important check on the other branches of government. Congress must have the ability to provide broad oversight, conduct investigations and make use of its subpoena power, just as we have throughout our nation’s history (1/6) https://t.co/Cv0eEHm7nE
